title: Can menstrual blood be collected and used for blood transfusion? - Quora

response.answer_text: To “Krista Delle Femine,” Toshima Karki (9 Feb. 2018), James Duncan (30 May 2019), and Cassandra Jefferson (5 Feb 2017), tl;dr — Menstrual blood cannot be used for blood transfusion. It is not sterile or pure, and it would not pass the health criteria needed. It would also clogged up the needle! Menstruation blood is contaminated with a mix of dead and live blood cells, unwelcome bacteria from the vagina flora, blood clots, and dead epithelial skin cells sloughed off from the lining of the uterus. Menstrual blood could not be cleansed for use in a blood transfusion. So, no it would not be possible to use this type of blood in a transfusion (if nothing else, it could kill the patient, and it would be far too thick to go through the needle!) — unless you were some cruel Nazi “doctor” back in the Holocaust who might even have tried to do the same thing on concentration camp prisoners/victims as one of their many evil “medical experiments.” I coordinate blood drives for the American Red Cross, and have donated over 14 gallons of whole blood over the years. Blood collectors’ standards for cleanliness are superb, but this type of blood product doesn’t begin to reach the sanity or sanitation needed for blood collection and transfusions. —Sarah M., posted 15 March 2019 (updated 2 August 2020)  ORIGINAL QUESTION: Not that anyone would, but is it possible to use menstruation blood in a transfusion, or is that blood “dead”? MERGED INTO: Can menstrual blood be collected and used for blood transfusion? (asked 5 February 2017)

No, due to following causes : The Menstrual blood contains of Blood and Fluid. Fluid includes vaginal secretions, cervical and endometrial mucus, also endometrium tissues. the blood is rich in ions which makes it heavier than flowing blood in body. During blood transfusion the pressure, temperature and respiratory rate is been checked.The color of menstrual blood is different as oxygen present in uterus reacts along with bacterias, as it stays for longer time which makes it look darker ! shredded tissues and decayed bacterias which makes typical odour which smells of sometimes like rotten fish or little bit of metallic as menstrual blood is rich in iron.For transfusion, the blood must contain platelets, plasma and haemoglobin rich in oxygen whereas the menstrual blood has less number of platelets than ordinary blood, also during transfusion antigens and antibodies are checked before use.So, menstrual blood can't be collected and used for transfusion or else if done it may kill patient.

“Menstrual blood” is NOT just blood - it is in fact the sloughed endometrium of the uterus mixed with some blood… Then the “blood” has traversed the vaginal vault, an din doing so has been mixed with the vaginal microbiology present there… Perhaps, a few red cells would even be viable but the profound effort that it would take to isolate them from the rest of the cellular and bacterial debris makes it a less than useful exercise… Not that anyone would…yes…

Menstrual blood has little oxygen carrying capacity! The purpose of blood transfusion is to increase the delivery of oxygen from the lungs to the peripheral tissues. Menstrual blood is composed of endometrial tissue and some blood from components. It would be difficult to harvest oxygen carrying cells from the mixture.

In theory yes but there are multiple problems: It's going to be hard to collectThe volume is not particularly highI expect by the time it's collected, it would not be in the best stateThere does not exist any apparatus to collect it for purposes of transfusionIt would have started to clot and finallyIt will be difficult to filter off the bacteria and bits of endometrium and the risk: benefit ratio is just not there.Edit: spelling.

No. It contains uterine tissue, which is a known activator of the coagulation pathway, and could lead to massive disseminated intravascular coagulopathy, a serious complication. There is also an issue with sterility. Do not try it at home.
Menstrual blood is mixed with a lot of different issues. It’s not the kind of blood circulating in your veins. And that is not usable for transfusions.
